subject: Chemistry
statement_full_text:
Personal Statement

I am enamoured with the idea that we can interact with the world on a molecular level, a scale so small and intangible and yet still known to us. My interest stems from this curiosity, where it developed into an appreciation for physical chemistry, a desire to observe molecules and their behaviours. What really captivates me is a relatively modern form of chemistry; A field first developed as Heitler and London put pen to paper, utilising Schrodinger's equation to map out the interaction between two hydrogen atoms. The history of quantum chemistry alone is inspiring. Shaped by the collaboration of countless physicists and chemists, it truly encapsulates the scientific world, but its applications are even more impressive. From predicting material properties to modelling drug activity in the body, quantum chemistry is a tool for understanding. It's a framework that allows us to decode the interactions between molecules and truly demonstrates the scope of chemistry; Because chemistry isn't just as small as a molecule you study, it's vast and elusive, and we can only hope to keep expanding the boundaries of what we know, which I know I will spend my life achieving.

I've been engrossed by bonding and the interactions between molecules, learning the behaviours of molecules and what causes them. Learning about particle interactions encouraged me to consider the importance of quantum mechanics in chemistry. These concepts inspired me to get involved with my subjects further, which is why I undertook the STEM SMART programme. This gave me the opportunity to explore chemistry at a greater depth through intricate problems that extend beyond the A-level. Having complex oxidation state problems explained by established academics gave me insight into how to develop my thinking to comprehend new ideas, establishing a more critical approach to learning like an academic should. Learning about electron configuration this year had me wondering if anything else I learned had been simplified to make it digestible, leading me to research more advanced concepts independently. I read articles about the attainment of a single electron covalent bond, which completely changed my perception on the limits of what we consider fact. I was surprised that Pauling theorised a covalent bond with just one electron nearly 100 years ago, but the fact that it was recently achieved is what really stunned me. This introduced me to the thrill of being proven wrong, reminding me that chemistry is not about studying facts, but challenging them in the pursuit of truth and understanding.

I participated in the Lucy Cavendish college outreach programme, where I joined peer discussion groups to consider various social issues. This made me look at chemistry in the context of ethical dilemma and its position in the causes or solutions. I read papers that delve into the set of ethical issues that chemists face, as a chemist's research can have unimaginable effects, such as environmental degradation or the use of chemical weapons in war. As chemists are the ones developing these substances they must confront the ethical implications, which showed me that a good chemist is aware of the bad parts of science, but that they're determined to do it right. I attended online taster lectures held by the University of Cambridge, which helped me get a feel for education beyond the setting I was used to. These taster sessions introduced me to the process of NMR, which particularly captivated me; The idea that you can determine the structure of a molecule by utilising spin states and energy levels had me enthralled. Engaging with this quickly proved valuable, as NMR appeared in the Cambridge chemistry challenge. The challenge pushed my thinking skills to their limits, giving me the chance to utilise techniques and knowledge I had developed independently, reflecting the effort I've put into immersing myself into the world chemistry.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You haven't really got any proper sections in here. A proper section means introducing a point, explaining where you got that from (lecture, book, course), then explaining the theory or process beyond A-level, linking it to a case study or paper, and explaining your conclusion with reasoning and sources. Your entire statement is essentially a descriptive overview of random thoughts with no real sections at all.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Create proper sections with structure: introduce point → explain source → explain theory/process (beyond A-level) → link to case study/paper → explain conclusion with reasoning and sources used

feedback_items.weak_passage: I am enamoured with the idea that we can interact with the world on a molecular level, a scale so small and intangible and yet still known to us. My interest stems from this curiosity, where it developed into an appreciation for physical chemistry, a desire to observe molecules and their behaviours.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is not really anything of substance. You're doing multiple intros without getting to any actual point. We've done 7 intros already before you even start talking about something specific. These opening sentences could be cut entirely.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut all the vague introductory sentences. Start with 'I like/find molecular chemistry interesting' and go straight into specific content.

feedback_items.weak_passage: A field first developed as Heitler and London put pen to paper, utilising Schrodinger's equation
feedback_items.your_feedback: Is that actually true? It sounds kind of oversimplified. Do you want to just double check the detail in there? Also, in terms of 'relatively modern' - we're talking century plus, aren't we? Check that too.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Verify the accuracy and add more nuanced detail about the development of quantum chemistry. Clarify what 'relatively modern' means in this context.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The history of quantum chemistry alone is inspiring. Shaped by the collaboration of countless physicists and chemists, it truly encapsulates the scientific world, but its applications are even more impressive.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Another intro, all right, that's not really anything. I'm still waiting for you to get to the point. I'm waiting for you to say 'This chemistry discovery was this. This is how it worked. This is why it was interesting. This is the impact it had and this is the paper I looked at to study it.'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace vague statements with specific content: name a specific discovery, explain how it worked, explain its impact, cite papers you read, describe experiments or analysis you conducted.

feedback_items.weak_passage: From predicting material properties to modelling drug activity in the body, quantum chemistry is a tool for understanding. It's a framework that allows us to decode the interactions between molecules
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're just listing things. This whole paragraph needs to go, basically. That whole paragraph could just be 'I find molecular chemistry interesting, full stop' and then go straight into actual content.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this entire paragraph. Replace with one sentence stating your interest, then immediately begin with specific academic content.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Chemistry isn't just as small as a molecule you study, it's vast and elusive, and we can only hope to keep expanding the boundaries of what we know, which I know I will spend my life achieving.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You haven't said a single thing that is specific to you. Any single person could put this, and it would still make sense for them. It doesn't belong in a personal statement.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace generic statements with content that is unique to your learning journey - specific discoveries you made, particular problems you solved, individual conclusions you drew.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I've been engrossed by bonding and the interactions between molecules. Learning about particle interactions encouraged me to consider the importance of quantum mechanics in chemistry. These concepts inspired me to get involved with my subjects further
feedback_items.your_feedback: Same as previous paragraph unfortunately. You're engrossed by bonding, you looked at quantum mechanics - let's please make a point. You're inspired to get involved, OK now we're finally talking about an actual thing, STEM Smart.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove the buildup and go directly into discussing STEM Smart with specific examples of what you learned.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This gave me the opportunity to explore chemistry at a greater depth through intricate problems that extend beyond the A-level.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't actually say anything that you learned. You just say this gave you an opportunity to explore chemistry at greater depth or intricate problems. What problems, I'll never know. Beyond A level, again, I'll never know.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Specify exactly what problems you solved, what concepts you learned, what was beyond A-level about them.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Having complex oxidation state problems explained by established academics
feedback_items.your_feedback: From what I remember from A level, is that not an A-level concept? So I would just maybe pick a different one. Also, which academics are you gonna tell me?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Choose an example that is clearly beyond A-level. Name the specific academics if you're going to mention them.

feedback_items.weak_passage: gave me insight into how to develop my thinking to comprehend new ideas, establishing a more critical approach to learning like an academic should
feedback_items.your_feedback: Gave you insight into how to develop my thinking. What insight? How, what are these new ideas? More critical approach, like an academic should, where, how? Do you know what I mean?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain what specific insights you gained, what new ideas you learned, how your thinking changed with concrete examples.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Learning about electron configuration this year had me wondering if anything else I had learned had been simplified to make it digestible, leading me to research more advanced concepts independently. I read articles
feedback_items.your_feedback: Why does that matter? What advanced concepts? What articles? You said 'I read articles' but you don't tell me which ones or what you learned from them.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Name the specific articles, explain what advanced concepts you learned, describe how they differed from the simplified version.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I was surprised that Pauling theorised a covalent bond with just one electron nearly 100 years ago, but the fact that it was recently achieved is what really stunned me.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You said you were surprised by this thing about Pauling. That's not an academic point. The rest of it just goes on and on of much of the same.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Instead of saying you're surprised, explain the chemistry: how the single electron bond works, what the experimental achievement involved, what implications it has for bonding theory.

feedback_items.weak_passage: These taster sessions introduced me to the process of NMR, which particularly captivated me; The idea that you can determine the structure of a molecule by utilising spin states and energy levels had me enthralled. Engaging with this quickly proved valuable
feedback_items.your_feedback: You mention NMR but you don't mention anything about it. You just say it captivated you. Engaging with this is valuable. Do you see what I mean? Like, this is not a kind of job interview about what skills you have. This is, how much chemistry do you know and how much have you studied.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain the NMR process in detail: how spin states work, what you learned about energy levels, how you applied this knowledge in the Cambridge chemistry challenge.

feedback_items.your_feedback: It's annoying because I know you could, you have the skills to do it. I'm sure you just didn't know that you had to do it in this particular way. But the whole thing needs to kind of be redone a little bit, I'll be honest, because this is not at the moment a personal statement, especially for where you're applying.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: You've done all the work, you just need to put it on paper. Restructure everything with proper academic sections showing depth of knowledge.

subject: Economics
statement_full_text:
Question 1: Why do you want to study this course or subject?

My economics journey has been quite eventful this year; studying economics for the first time has led to ups and downs, but one thing is for sure: my curiousity and personal growth in this subject has led to my interest being sparked. Initially, the concept of how Economics has its everyday uses, as learnt in year 1 microeconomics grabbed my attention and how economics can be applied in various other topics – it is a very flexible subject. To explore further, I completed the University of Cambridge's 'Foundations of Finance' MOOC, where I delved into the quantitative side of economics, such as the calculations of equities. As a result of this, I realised that economics isn't just about theory—it's a powerful way to interpret and influence the world.

Question 2: How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course or subject?

In terms of preparedness for the course, I've actively developed the analytical skills economics demands. Competing in the Great British Economics Olympiad 2025 (where I progressed through two rounds) tested my ability to apply economic principles to complex, time-pressured scenarios. Similarly, earning a Gold award in the Maths IMC strengthened my problem-solving agility, which lead to me using this skill in weekly maths mentoring sessions, helping younger students grasp abstract concepts. Even my volunteering as a science club assistant has been surprisingly relevant—breaking down experiments for peers improved my ability to communicate technical ideas clearly, a skill vital for interpreting economic data. I also read Freakonomics by Levitt and Dubner—its unique approach revealed how data could decode human behaviour, from incentive-driven cheating to the hidden impact of names on success. This interest lead me to writing a critical review for my school journal pushed me to engage deeply with their methods, sparking my curiousity in how economic thinking challenges assumptions. On the topic of extended writing, I also took part in the 2025 essay competition hosted by the LSESU Economics Society, which resulted in directly improving my essay writing skills, developing my ability to read around the subject and correctly cite information where necessary. This research also fuelled my enjoyment on the topic of how AI can be both positively and negatively influential in the work place, in terms of economic growth.

Question 3: What else have you done to prepare outside of education, and why are these experiences useful?

Beyond school academics, I've learned to thrive in both collaborative and independent settings. As a volunteer for precinct computer room monitoring, I balanced assisting peers with managing my own workload—a foundational skill that mirrors the self-discipline needed for the stepping stone into degree-level study. Furthermore, through the STEM Smart Programme, I contribute to weekly maths problems designed to develop critical thinking, sharpening my ability to frame problems creatively and explain solutions logically. Also, on a slightly more personal note, I have noticed myself start to think about scenarios through a more economical lens; for example, my father works in a fairly modest corner shop. This naturally resulted in some of our conversations drifting toward his work-life such as demand and supply or how external shocks e.g. a heatwave melting chocolate, can shift consumer behaviour, reducing overall purchases and then lowering demand. At times, I have helped out at the shop myself. Initially, I saw this as just a waste of time and a distraction, but this experience opened my eyes – showing me how closely economics connects to everyday life, even in a small retail setting. From observing how pricing decisions were made to weighing the cost-benefit of stocking certain products over others, I began to recognise the practical application of theories I have encountered in class. What I first perceived as a loss of study-time and a distraction became an invaluable to develop time management skills, gain insight into microeconomic principles in action, and deepen my enthusiasm for the subject. This experience, along with my achievement in the Economics Olympiad, has taught me how to approach open-ended questions methodically and has enabled me to grow as a person. With this foundation of skill and enthusiasm, I look forward to embracing university economics as the next stage in my prospective journey.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You couldn't do land economy with this particular personal statement. You can only really apply for economics, to be honest with you.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: If you want to apply for Cambridge Land Economy, you'll need to rewrite the statement to cover the broader topics required for that course.

feedback_items.your_feedback: I think you're a good writer - your writing's very nice and clear. Overall though, I would say it's a little bit too anecdotal. A lot of it is just very storytelling, it's quite shallow. What you're lacking in your personal statement is depth. It's literally just a writing problem.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Shift from storytelling to academic depth. Focus on explaining concepts, your analysis, conclusions drawn, rather than describing experiences.
feedback_items.strong_passage: I think you're a good writer, to be fair. I think your writing's very nice and clear.
feedback_items.why_strong: The student has strong fundamental writing skills, which makes the fixes easier to implement.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My economics journey has been quite eventful this year; studying economics for the first time has led to ups and downs, but one thing is for sure: my curiousity and personal growth in this subject has led to my interest being sparked. Initially, the concept of how Economics has its everyday uses
feedback_items.your_feedback: Up until 'to explore further' those first few sentences are not the best. It's really difficult to talk abstractly or vaguely about economics and say anything meaningful and authentic. All of this stuff about curiosity, personal growth, interest being sparked, everyday uses - it's just bread and butter, it's supposed to have been done. I would just personally cut that.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Start with: 'I am interested in economics. I became interested when I completed the University of Cambridge Finance Foundations of Finance MOOC.' Go straight into specific content.

feedback_items.weak_passage: such as the calculations of equities. As a result of this, I realised that economics isn't just about theory—it's a powerful way to interpret and influence the world.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The calculation of equities is not the best conclusion to draw from a MOOC, I'll be honest. You need to bring out something more academic than that - it's really nothing from an academic tutor point of view. Also, academic tutors in economics don't love finance - finance is kind of the vocational part, not the area you want to talk loads about. That conclusion about economics being powerful would be lovely to put somewhere else, but just not when it comes to finance.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Use this MOOC section to discuss stats and modelling, high level stuff like R or cool regressions. Spend 3-4 sentences developing an idea: 'I learned this skill, I calculated this, I found this interesting, I had to calculate within these parameters with these limitations.' Link to real world events you observed.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In terms of preparedness for this course, I've actively developed the analytical skills economics demands. Competing in the Great British Economics Olympiad 2025 (where I progressed through two rounds) tested my ability to apply economic principles
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're being too literal. You're literally trying to tell them how you're prepared. Make sure your tutors are not including the Olympiad stuff in your reference, because oftentimes they will do it, in which case you don't need it here. Until the mentoring sessions, this top bit is a little bit vague, it's a little bit of storytelling - you're not actually telling me how you solved a problem.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Say: 'During the maths IMC, one of the questions that was really interesting was [state the question], here's how I solved it. At first I was gonna do this, then I looked at this. This is a really interesting problem. I actually went and Googled it later, and there was another more difficult problem where the same concepts are applied.' That would be wonderful.

feedback_items.weak_passage: helping younger students grasp abstract concepts. Even my volunteering as a science club assistant has been surprisingly relevant—breaking down experiments for peers improved my ability to communicate technical ideas clearly
feedback_items.your_feedback: This stuff about helping younger students and Science Club Assistant should really be in the last section, like one sentence at the end. It doesn't really need more than that. You don't need this stuff about communicating technical ideas, they already know that.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Move these activities to Q3 and compress to one sentence each.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I also read Freakonomics by Levitt and Dubner—its unique approach revealed how data could decode human behaviour
feedback_items.your_feedback: For economics, Levitt and Dubner is quite a basic book. It's technically more of a popular interest book, not an academics book. However, it is still interesting. So it's fine to use that as your starting point. However, should you just leave that and then run away, potentially not.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Include a different academic article from there. Go onto our site, use the buddy thing to say 'can you give me a book that's like similar ideas to Freakonomics, but higher level, more difficult.' It will give you one. Read that or a different article and link it in - it can help you develop your ideas better.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This interest lead me to writing a critical review for my school journal pushed me to engage deeply with their methods, sparking my curiousity in how economic thinking challenges assumptions.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is fine but if you could actually say what you wrote and what conclusions you drew, that would be good. Instead of talking about 'I can cite information, I can improve my essay skills, I can develop my ability to read' - that is all a given. I have no doubt you can do that. Can you instead tell me what your conclusions were, what your arguments were, what you quoted, what your sources were?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain: what arguments did you make in the review? What conclusions did you draw? What sources did you cite? What was your thesis?

feedback_items.weak_passage: I also took part in the 2025 essay competition hosted by the LSESU Economics Society, which resulted in directly improving my essay writing skills, developing my ability to read around the subject and correctly cite information where necessary. This research also fuelled my enjoyment on the topic of how AI can be both positively and negatively influential in the work place
feedback_items.your_feedback: Same with this essay competition. Instead of talking about improving essay skills and citing information - that is all a given. Can you tell me what your conclusions were, what your arguments were, what you quoted, what your sources were? The topic of AI came out of nowhere. You didn't even give me the title of your essay. You can't say that.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: State the essay title. Explain your main arguments, conclusions, and key sources cited. If discussing AI, properly introduce and develop the topic.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Beyond school academics, I've learned to thrive in both collaborative and independent settings. As a volunteer for precinct computer room monitoring, I balanced assisting peers with managing my own workload—a foundational skill that mirrors the self-discipline needed
feedback_items.your_feedback: It's too long, this section. Up until 'furthermore,' you don't really need that. Can you just list it all off and say 'look, I am seen as a leader in my school. I volunteer for precinct computer room monitoring, I mentor students in weekly maths and I am Science clubs assistant' - full stop, that can all just be one sentence.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Compress all extracurriculars into one sentence listing them, unless you want to say what one of the STEM smart problems was - that would be more interesting.

feedback_items.weak_passage: my father works in a fairly modest corner shop. This naturally resulted in some of our conversations drifting toward his work-life such as demand and supply or how external shocks e.g. a heatwave melting chocolate, can shift consumer behaviour, reducing overall purchases and then lowering demand. At times, I have helped out at the shop myself. Initially, I saw this as just a waste of time and a distraction, but this experience opened my eyes
feedback_items.your_feedback: The stuff about the corner shop is actually quite interesting, but it's too long. That's at least 5-6 sentences. It's just way too long. Just focus on the main points - working at my family corner shop, I saw in real life how pricing decisions can be made by cost benefit stocking certain products over others and the demand supply. If you move that sentence up to the top, that could be your 'how I became interested' thing, but cut the rest of it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Reduce to 2-3 sentences max. Focus on the economics: 'Working at my family corner shop, I observed how pricing decisions were made by cost-benefit analysis of stocking products, and how demand-supply dynamics played out in real time.'
feedback_items.strong_passage: I actually think that part is actually quite interesting
feedback_items.why_strong: The corner shop example provides genuine real-world application of economic principles.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This experience, along with my achievement in the Economics Olympiad, has taught me how to approach open-ended questions methodically
feedback_items.your_feedback: Economics Olympiad - if you just wanted to mention a particular problem you found interesting and how you solved it, that would be much better.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Describe one specific Olympiad problem: state the question, explain how you approached it, what solution you found.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You have all the right elements. You don't actually need to do too much other stuff. You could do a couple more readings and things, but it's actually fine. I hope you see my point on how to make this slightly more developed and academic.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Focus on restructuring what you have to be more academic and specific. Add a couple more readings if time permits.

subject: PPE
statement_full_text:
Q1) My interest in politics and economics stems from a desire to understand how sustainable growth and prosperity can be achieved in developing nations.
Watching a lecture by Dercon on 'Gambling on Development', I agreed with the notion that the commitment of elites to growth over rent-seeking is key to long-run growth. I found this convincing when applied to my home country, Sri Lanka. Elites pursued political gain through populist policies, such as large tax cuts, contributing to the country's economic crisis.
Reading North's 'Violence and Social Order', I concluded that inclusive political institutions and open markets are key in explaining why 'open access order' societies achieve greater economic growth. When applying North's theory to Dercon's 'development bargain', I found that Dercon was focusing his argument on whether elites are committed to moving from a basic natural state to a mature state. Yet, a mature state may not evolve into an 'open-access order', depending on whether elites choose to use the state's institutions to promote broader societal development. This led me to conclude that Dercon's 'development bargain' only describes a particular stage of institutional development in North's theory, undermining his argument that a development bargain will necessarily lead to growth. I was particularly convinced by North's argument that rents created through state intervention can serve positive purposes, especially Schumpeterian rents that incentivise innovation. I found this exemplified by China's state-led industrial and technological policy, where deliberate rent creation underpinned rapid growth.
Q2) Studying A-level politics exposed me to the Westminster model, where power is concentrated in the executive. This creates a "tyranny of the majority" which often limits considered policymaking. This led me to question whether a consensus democracy might better serve the UK. I found Lijphart's 'Patterns of Democracy' convincing in its case for consensus democracy, particularly wider power-sharing to limit executive overreach and reduce the risk of misguided policies, such as Blair's invasion of Iraq. My studies in economics led me to question how globalisation and macroeconomic policy constrain redistribution. Rodrik's 'Globalization paradox' challenged my assumption that freer trade is inherently beneficial, showing that gains from further liberalisation are limited and involve significant redistributive trade-offs, as income and jobs decline for workers in less competitive sector. I found his proposal to liberalise labour mobility compelling. However, his claim that democracies should preserve domestic distributional bargains was unconvincing. These bargains, which are agreements on how gains from globalisation are shared, often favour profitable industries while offering limited support for low skilled workers. This can deepen inequality. This led me to question how globalisation's benefits could be distributed more equitably.

Q3) Selected for an International European Youth Parliament session, I developed research skills through exploring the 'brain drain'. Leading Model UN society strengthened my ability to construct and defend arguments. A MOOC deepened my interested in the relationship between inequality and growth. I contrasted Kuznet's view that inequality naturally declines with development with Piketty's argument that capitalism inherently sustains it. Yet, I found both perspectives unconvincing, as globalisation has produced uneven effects on inequality. I found Lakner and Milanovic's 'Elephant curve' convincing in demonstrating how middle-income groups in emerging economies saw significant reductions in inequality, while low-income workers in advanced economies experienced stagnation. I questioned how inequality could be addressed. This inspired me to write an article exploring Milanovic's proposal to reduce concentration of capital, which I argued could be achieved through the creation of a social welfare fund.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My interest in politics and economics stems from a desire to understand how sustainable growth and prosperity can be achieved in developing nations. After watching a lecture by Dercon on 'Gambling on Development', I agreed that
feedback_items.your_feedback: Think you could probably combine/pick one opening here
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Choose either the personal interest statement or jump directly into the Dercon lecture. Combining both makes the opening slightly redundant.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I concluded that the authoritarian model enabled ineffective populist policies to be implemented. Thus, increasing debt and leading me to understand ethnic majoritarianism can hinder long-run development.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Where did you get this idea from? A source would be useful
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cite a source for your conclusion about the authoritarian model in Sri Lanka and ethnic majoritarianism hindering development.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Dercon focuses his argument on whether elites are committed to moving from a basic natural state to a mature state. Yet, a mature state may not evolve into an 'open-access order', depending on whether elites choose to use state institutions to promote broader societal development. So, Dercon's 'development bargain' only describes a particular stage of institutional development in North's theory
feedback_items.your_feedback: Solid section - other parts need to be more like this!
feedback_items.strong_passage: Reading North's 'Violence and Social Orders', I concluded that open access to political and economic institutions was key in explaining why open-access order societies experience greater stability and economic growth. When applying North's theory to Dercon's 'development bargain', I concluded that Dercon was focusing his argument on whether elites are committed to moving from a basic natural state to a mature state. However, a mature state may or may not evolve into an open-access order, depending on whether elites choose to use the state's structures to benefit society more broadly. This led me to deduce that Dercon's "development bargain" is only describing a particular stage of institutional development in North's theory, undermining his argument that a development bargain will necessarily lead to growth.
feedback_items.why_strong: This section demonstrates strong analytical thinking by synthesizing two theoretical frameworks (North and Dercon) and drawing an original conclusion about their relationship. The argument is clear, well-structured, and shows genuine intellectual engagement.

feedback_items.weak_passage: as demonstrated in East Asia where industrial policy and deliberate rent creation underpinned rapid growth.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Slightly vague on point about East Asia but you get away with it just about - probably worth at least stating the countries though, East Asia is lots of different places!!
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Name specific countries (e.g., South Korea, Taiwan, Japan) rather than just saying 'East Asia'.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Reading Lijphart's Patterns of Democracy, I found his case for dispersing political power convincing, as it could reduce executive dominance and the likelihood of unpopular policy, such as Blair's decision to invade Iraq.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You need someone else to check this bit: Reading Lijphart's Patterns of Democracy, I found his case for dispersing political power convincing, as it could reduce executive dominance and the likelihood of unpopular policy. Writing wise seems okay
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Have another person verify the accuracy of your interpretation of Lijphart's argument about consensus democracy and executive overreach.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I found his alternative solution of liberalising labour markets particularly compelling.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Fairly good section - only thing is you might want to double-check that Rodrik reading. From what I recall, he argues for liberalising labour mobility not markets. Labour market liberalisation actually is not good for vulnerable worker groups in the most direct/simple sense of it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Change 'liberalising labour markets' to 'liberalising labour mobility'. These are different concepts - verify which one Rodrik actually advocates for.
feedback_items.strong_passage: My studies in economics led me to question how globalisation and macroeconomic policy constrain redistribution. Rodrik's 'Globalization Paradox' challenged my assumption that freer trade is inherently beneficial, instead leading me to conclude that the gains from further trade liberalisation are limited and come with significant redistribution trade-offs.
feedback_items.why_strong: Shows genuine intellectual growth - challenging previous assumptions and engaging critically with economic theory.

feedback_items.weak_passage: However, I found his claim that democracies should preserve domestically agreed distributional bargains unconvincing, as such arrangements often deepen inequality and limit opportunities for the poor.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Then also double-check point after about 'domestically agreed distributional bargains'... need to be clearer here about what you think Rodrik means and what you therefore think.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Clarify your understanding of Rodrik's concept of 'distributional bargains'. Explain more precisely what he means and why you disagree.

feedback_items.weak_passage: as I facilitated discussions on issues such as immigration, debt relief and resource exploitation.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Bit general with listing out discussion topics but fine
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either remove the list of topics or pick one and explain what perspectives you encountered or what you learned.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Writing an article on the private sector's role in increasing welfare loss, I concluded that rising monopoly power limits competition through high barriers to entry, reducing allocative efficiency and driving inequality.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Last sentence is basically A Level - bringing in a new idea would be better
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: This monopoly analysis is A-level economics. Either remove it or extend it with more sophisticated economic theory beyond A-level (e.g., dynamic efficiency considerations, regulatory capture, Schumpeterian innovation).
feedback_items.strong_passage: Completing a MOOC I was introduced to Olson's "stationary bandit" model – which I found convincing in explaining how predictable taxation can substitute for force, providing citizens with incentives to comply.
feedback_items.why_strong: Introduces a beyond-A-level concept (Olson's model) with clear explanation of its significance.

subject: PPE
statement_full_text:
Q1)
My interest in politics and economics stems from a desire to understand how growth and welfare can be achieved in developing nations. Personal connection to Sri Lanka led me to me to investigate reasons behind their worst economic crisis. I concluded that the authoritarian model enabled ineffective populist policies to be implemented. Thus, increasing debt and .leading me to understand ethnic majoritarianism can hinder long-run development.
Watching an LSE lecture by Dercon on 'Gambling on Development' first sparked my interest in development economics. I agreed with the notion that elite commitment to growth over rent-seeking is key to long-run growth. Observing how countries with weak state capacity could use NGOs and the private sector to drive development, as I saw in Bangladesh, challenged my assumption that only strong states can lead to growth. I was left questioning how elite bargains change as countries reach the middle-income trap and face rising demands for political rights, as seen in Taiwan and South Korea.
Reading North's 'Violence and Social Orders', I concluded that open access to political and economic institutions was key in explaining why open-access order societies experience greater stability and economic development. When applying North's theory to Dercon's 'development bargain', I concluded that Dercon was focusing his argument on whether elites are committed to moving from a basic natural state to a mature state. However, a mature state may or may not evolve into an open-access order, depending on whether elites choose to use the state's structures to benefit society more broadly. This led me to deduce that Dercon's "development bargain" is only describing a particular stage of institutional development in North's theory, undermining his argument that a development bargain will necessarily lead to growth. I found North's argument that rents can serve positive purposes particularly convincing, especially Schumpeterian rents that incentivise innovation, as demonstrated in East Asia where industrial policy and deliberate rent creation underpinned rapid growth.

Q2) Studying A-level politics exposed me to the concentrated nature of the Westminster model, leading me to question whether proportional representation is a better alternative for the UK. Reading Lijphart's Patterns of Democracy, I found his case for dispersing political power convincing, as it could reduce executive dominance and the likelihood of unpopular policy, such as Blair's decision to invade Iraq. My studies in economics, led me to question how globalisation and macroeconomic policy constrain redistribution. Rodrik's 'Globalization Paradox' challenged my assumption that freer trade is inherently beneficial, instead leading me to conclude that the gains from further trade liberalisation are limited and come with significant redistribution trade-offs. I found his alternative solution of liberalising labour markets, particularly compelling. However, I found his claim that democracies should preserve domestically agreed distributional bargains unconvincing, as such arrangements often deepen inequality and limit opportunities for the poor. This led me to question how the gains from globalisation might be distributed more equitably.

Q3
Selected for an International European Youth Parliament session, I developed extensive research skills through exploring the 'brain drain'. Leading my school's Model UN society allowed me to develop my skills in defending and construct arguments, as I facilitated discussions on issues such as immigration, debt relief and resource exploitation. Completing a MOOC I was introduced to Olson's ''stationary bandit'' model – which I foud convincing in explaining how predictable taxation can substitute for force, providing citizens with incentives to comply. Writing an article on the private sector's role in increasing welfare loss. I concluded that rising monopoly power limits competition through high barriers to entry, reducing allocative efficiency and driving inequality.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My interest in politics and economics stems from a desire to understand how growth and welfare can be achieved in developing nations. Personal connection to Sri Lanka led me to me to investigate reasons behind their worst economic crisis.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Think you could probably combine/pick one opening here
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Choose either the general interest statement or the Sri Lanka connection as your opening, not both. They're redundant together.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I concluded that the authoritarian model enabled ineffective populist policies to be implemented. Thus, increasing debt and .leading me to understand ethnic majoritarianism can hinder long-run development.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Where did you get this idea from? A source would be useful
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Provide a source for this conclusion about Sri Lanka's authoritarian model and ethnic majoritarianism. This is a specific claim that needs academic backing.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Observing how countries with weak state capacity could use NGOs and the private sector to drive development, as I saw in Bangladesh, challenged my assumption that only strong states can lead to growth.
feedback_items.your_feedback: What did you see in Bangladesh? Sounds like you're referring to something you already mentioned. Not clear what you're observing here and what link is between NGO/development. Also unclear where you stated only strong states can lead to growth? Feels like there's a section missing here
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain what specifically you observed about Bangladesh. Clarify the NGO/development connection. You haven't previously stated the assumption about strong states, so either establish that first or remove the reference to challenging it.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I was left questioning how elite bargains change as countries reach the middle-income trap and face rising demands for political rights, as seen in Taiwan and South Korea.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Again name-dropping country examples with no support/evidence. You need to include much more specific detail here or at least state more clearly what your points are i.e. NGOs do x therefore causing y and so z.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either remove the Taiwan and South Korea references or explain specifically what happened in these countries regarding elite bargains and the middle-income trap.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Reading North's 'Violence and Social Orders', I concluded that open access to political and economic institutions was key in explaining why open-access order societies experience greater stability and economic development. When applying North's theory to Dercon's 'development bargain', I concluded that Dercon was focusing his argument on whether elites are committed to moving from a basic natural state to a mature state. However, a mature state may or may not evolve into an open-access order, depending on whether elites choose to use the state's structures to benefit society more broadly. This led me to deduce that Dercon's "development bargain" is only describing a particular stage of institutional development in North's theory, undermining his argument that a development bargain will necessarily lead to growth. I found North's argument that rents can serve positive purposes particularly convincing, especially Schumpeterian rents that incentivise innovation
feedback_items.your_feedback: Solid section - other parts need to be more like this!
feedback_items.strong_passage: Reading North's 'Violence and Social Orders', I concluded that open access to political and economic institutions was key in explaining why open-access order societies experience greater stability and economic development. When applying North's theory to Dercon's 'development bargain', I concluded that Dercon was focusing his argument on whether elites are committed to moving from a basic natural state to a mature state. However, a mature state may or may not evolve into an open-access order, depending on whether elites choose to use the state's structures to benefit society more broadly. This led me to deduce that Dercon's "development bargain" is only describing a particular stage of institutional development in North's theory, undermining his argument that a development bargain will necessarily lead to growth.
feedback_items.why_strong: This demonstrates sophisticated theoretical synthesis, applying North's framework to critique Dercon's argument. Shows original thinking and deep engagement with academic sources.

feedback_items.weak_passage: as demonstrated in East Asia where industrial policy and deliberate rent creation underpinned rapid growth.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Slightly vague on point about East Asia but you get away with it just about - probably worth at least stating the countries though, East Asia is lots of different places!!
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Name specific countries (e.g., South Korea, Taiwan, Japan, Singapore) rather than just 'East Asia'.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Studying A-level politics exposed me to the concentrated nature of the Westminster model
feedback_items.your_feedback: 'How the Westminster model concentrates power ...' could be better - bit vague as it currently is, but ignore if it conflicts with your readings
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider rephrasing to: 'Studying A-level politics exposed me to how the Westminster model concentrates power in the executive' for clarity.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Reading Lijphart's Patterns of Democracy, I found his case for dispersing political power convincing, as it could reduce executive dominance and the likelihood of unpopular policy, such as Blair's decision to invade Iraq.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You need someone else to check this bit: Reading Lijphart's Patterns of Democracy, I found his case for dispersing political power convincing, as it could reduce executive dominance and the likelihood of unpopular policy. Writing wise seems okay
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Have another person verify that your interpretation of Lijphart accurately reflects his arguments about consensus democracy.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I found his alternative solution of liberalising labour markets, particularly compelling.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Fairly good section - only thing is you might want to double-check that Rodrik reading. From what I recall, he argues for liberalising labour mobility not markets. Labour market liberalisation actually is not good for vulnerable worker groups in the most direct/simple sense of it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Change 'liberalising labour markets' to 'liberalising labour mobility'. These are fundamentally different concepts with opposite implications for workers.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Rodrik's 'Globalization Paradox' challenged my assumption that freer trade is inherently beneficial, instead leading me to conclude that the gains from further trade liberalisation are limited and come with significant redistribution trade-offs.
feedback_items.why_strong: Shows intellectual growth and willingness to challenge prior assumptions based on academic reading.

feedback_items.weak_passage: However, I found his claim that democracies should preserve domestically agreed distributional bargains unconvincing, as such arrangements often deepen inequality and limit opportunities for the poor.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Then also double-check point after about 'domestically agreed distributional bargains' ... need to be clearer here about what you think Rodrik means and what you therefore think.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Clarify what Rodrik means by 'distributional bargains' and explain more precisely why you disagree with preserving them.

feedback_items.weak_passage: as I facilitated discussions on issues such as immigration, debt relief and resource exploitation.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Bit general with listing out discussion topics but fine
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either remove this list or pick one topic and explain what you learned or what perspectives you encountered.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Writing an article on the private sector's role in increasing welfare loss. I concluded that rising monopoly power limits competition through high barriers to entry, reducing allocative efficiency and driving inequality.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Last sentence is basically A Level - bringing in a new idea would be better
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: This monopoly analysis is standard A-level economics. Either remove it or extend with beyond-A-level concepts like dynamic efficiency, X-inefficiency, regulatory capture, or behavioral economics insights.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Completing a MOOC I was introduced to Olson's ''stationary bandit'' model – which I foud convincing in explaining how predictable taxation can substitute for force, providing citizens with incentives to comply.
feedback_items.why_strong: Introduces a sophisticated beyond-A-level concept with clear explanation of its significance.

subject: Law
statement_full_text:
My motivation to study law, stems from an experience that offered first-hand insight into its impact. My mother suffered from a stressing incident of medical negligence while receiving treatment during pregnancy; seeing the repercussions of a traumatic experience with the legal case that affect her, and my family ignited a passion to change the legal system and protect the rights of minorities and individuals who are entitled to fair representation and equal access to opportunities of justice. As I see it, law is the foundation of democracy as it sets to exemplify how people should be treated, how justice is upheld and how voices should be heard. My devotion to the study of law was furthered when I read Elizbeth Rosenthal's 'American Sickness' which while not focused on the United Kingdom, it impacted me as it offers a forewarning for any healthcare system. As it challenges lawyers and policymakers to rethink what ethical, patient -centred care and accountability should look like in the future, to continue meeting the standard of treatment we have established as a society want for ourselves. The topic of society and social change further reinforced my motivation to study law, as I have always been increasingly aware of the systemic inequalities that have been purged onto minorities and by engaging in discussion with a wide range of people who have different opinions on law-based debates it created a thirst to learn more from others experiences and debates in the profession. The podcast 'The Law Show' by BBC Radio 4 gave me a chance to broaden my knowledge on specific controversial topics. From the topic of assisted dying to the redevelopment of AI laws while also allowing me to form my opinion on how lawyers must be able to navigate picking between complex decisions that reflect on society.

While studying the African American Civil rights development as part of my module, we discussed and learnt about the evolution of laws and talked heavily about the societal change from 1863 to present day. The amendment laws to the Jim Crow laws became fascinating to me as a young black individual who was interested in the limited rights of black people to equality. Law is deeply based in historical events and showed me the growth of the legal systems in response to protests, politics, power, and origins of legal principles. It impacted the symbolisms of cases and historical knowledge to me through cases like Brown v The Board of education and Plessy V Ferguson. I researched heavily into key lawyers such as Thurgood Marshall and how his legal knowledge impacted the success of Civil Rights for Black Americans. It gave me insights on the principles of being a lawyer and how it may seem like a minor change to others it creates a massive impact on another individual.

I have delved into cases and trials myself by participating in my school's law societies mock trials. This allowed me to gain a deep understanding on how to gather information and the process of how legal cases plays out. I developed crucial skills that are used in law namely critical thinking and legal reasoning which allowed me to analyse facts, interpret legal principles, and build argument based on the evidence that was presented to me. I have also taken part in a psychology society where I delivered a presentation on the case of Utah vs Ruby Franke and Sara Sharif trial. This allowed me to home in on my skills of researching a case that was being highly debated and explore how the legal system responds to abuse and child protection laws. This experience deepened my knowledge of how the law interacts with mental health evidence and the justice's systems responsibility to protect the vulnerable.

My inquisitiveness for law flourishes outside of formal education, I have taken active steps to prepare for a career in law by immersing myself in both legal experiences and broader personal development. I am an active member of my school's law society I engaged with junior solicitors, apprentices and trainee lawyers which allowed me to gain first-hand insight into the realness of legal practice. Their acumen on casework and career routes helped me appreciate the complexity and human impact of law.

My commitment to the Silver and Gold Duke of Edinburgh Awards have equally been formative. Leading expeditions and coordinating group responsibilities have cultivated leadership, resilience and problem-solving-qualities that mirror the pressures and ethical responsibilities of faced legal professionals. During the volunteer component I volunteered at an elderly care charity which reinforced my awareness of social accountability, particularly in supporting marginalised groups, aligning closely with my interests of medical negligence law where outcomes profoundly affect individuals lives and wellbeing.

To enhance upon this foundation, I have participated in a range of legal and business enrichment programmes including Slaughter and May's virtual law experience, the University of Brighton outreach and Surrey's Scholar events, Lloyds Bank insight scheme, Springpod, and the Power up seminar for aspiring lawyers. These experiences exposed me to key areas of commercial law, client interaction, and the business side of legal services, while also promoting reflection on accountability in professional environments which is an idea central to clinical negligence cases.

As Head of student Diversity and inclusion, I have led initiatives that promote representation and fairness within my school community. Developing skills in communication and ethical leadership. My involvement with the Doncaster Youth Council and speaking in the House of Commons in parliament where I debated the advocation of more mental health professional training in schools further sparked my interest in the interface between legal structures and public accountability. Outside these activities I balance my academic studies with competitive first team and Club netball and school hockey which has instilled discipline, focus, ability to perform under pressure and competition. Traits I consider vital for the success in the legal field.

feedback_items.your_feedback: I think you've done really well, though, good sections, lots of interesting things that you're talking about.
feedback_items.why_strong: The statement has good foundational content and interesting experiences to draw from.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My motivation to study law, stems from an experience that offered first-hand insight into its impact. My mother suffered from a stressing incident of medical negligence while receiving treatment during pregnancy; seeing the repercussions of a traumatic experience with the legal case that affect her, and my family ignited a passion to change the legal system
feedback_items.your_feedback: The whole first paragraph needs to be cut down. It is very long. My motivation to study law stems from an experience - we don't need this kind of intro sentence. Unless you're actually going to tell me what the medical negligence was, go into detail and then tie more of your thoughts about it into it, it's a little bit pointless. It's way too long and not really much in it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either provide specific details about the medical negligence case and your analysis of it, or cut this entire personal story. If keeping it, make it 2-3 sentences maximum.

feedback_items.weak_passage: As I see it, law is the foundation of democracy as it sets to exemplify how people should be treated, how justice is upheld and how voices should be heard.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're giving a definition of law almost, but because it's a little bit simplistic, it doesn't help you. I actually think it's best to start with Elizabeth Rosenthal's American Sickness.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this definition. Start your statement with: 'I became interested in law when I read Elizabeth Rosenthal's American Sickness.'

feedback_items.weak_passage: which while not focused on the United Kingdom, it impacted me as it offers a forewarning for any healthcare system.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I'm not sure why you've said 'not focused on the UK. It impacts me as it offers a forewarning for any healthcare system.' That's totally unnecessary. You can find it interesting, even if it's not based in the UK. That's totally fine.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this sentence. Just discuss what you learned from the book.

feedback_items.weak_passage: As it challenges lawyers and policymakers to rethink what ethical, patient-centred care and accountability should look like in the future, to continue meeting the standard of treatment we have established as a society want for ourselves.
feedback_items.your_feedback: All of this is kind of sounding a little bit off point. Your whole thing is about law and policy, but you're going into a bit too much detail about what the standard of treatment should be in healthcare, if that makes sense. You've gone into detail, but not the right type of detail.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Focus on the legal and policy aspects rather than healthcare standards. Discuss what legal frameworks or accountability mechanisms the book proposes.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The topic of society and social change further reinforced my motivation to study law, as I have always been increasingly aware of the systemic inequalities that have been purged onto minorities
feedback_items.your_feedback: The topic of society and social change - it kind of comes out of nowhere, and I'd rather you just chose one and just developed it out well. You've become aware of systemic inequalities that have been purged onto minorities - again, there's no evidence, you don't really give me any data, so I'm just taking your word for it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Choose one specific topic (either American Sickness OR systemic inequalities) and develop it thoroughly with evidence. Don't jump between topics.

feedback_items.weak_passage: by engaging in discussion with a wide range of people who have different opinions on law-based debates it created a thirst to learn more from others experiences
feedback_items.your_feedback: You spend a lot of time talking about you having an interest and being pushed to do something, but you're not talking enough about the actual theories and the content in it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Instead of describing your interest being sparked, explain what specific legal theories or content you learned from these discussions.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The podcast 'The Law Show' by BBC Radio 4 gave me a chance to broaden my knowledge on specific controversial topics. From the topic of assisted dying to the redevelopment of AI laws while also allowing me to form my opinion
feedback_items.your_feedback: It gives you a chance to broaden my knowledge on specific controversial topics - assisted dying and AI laws - but you don't tell me more about it apart from that. You're just listing off things that you read.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Pick ONE episode (e.g., assisted dying). Explain: What were the legal arguments presented? What's happening in other countries? What did you find fascinating about the legal framework? That's 3 sentences maximum.

feedback_items.your_feedback: To summarise that first paragraph - that could be 3 sentences, honestly. I read Elizabeth Rosenthal's book. One conclusion she drew was this, and this has massive implications for law, full stop. Another area I like to keep up with the latest in law. The law show allows me to do this. One particularly interesting topic for me was some episode about assisted dying. They were saying this, this is what's happening in other countries. All of this is fascinating, full stop.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Restructure to: (1) State you read Rosenthal's book + one key conclusion with legal implications. (2) Mention The Law Show as how you stay current. (3) Discuss one episode in detail with what you learned.

feedback_items.weak_passage: While studying the African American Civil rights development as part of my module, we discussed and learnt about the evolution of laws and talked heavily about the societal change from 1863 to present day. The amendment laws to the Jim Crow laws became fascinating to me
feedback_items.your_feedback: That's a good topic to discuss, but then you just say it's interesting. But then you don't actually say what you learned. Again, you don't really say like what you learned, so you just said the amendment laws to the Jim Crow laws became fascinating to me. But no detail about what happened, why it's interesting, any particular extra readings that you did as a result of that.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain WHAT happened with the Jim Crow laws amendments. WHY was it fascinating? What extra readings did you do? What did you learn from those readings?

feedback_items.weak_passage: Law is deeply based in historical events and showed me the growth of the legal systems in response to protests, politics, power, and origins of legal principles.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're saying like the growth of the legal system, but then you don't tell me what the growth was. I'd rather you just told me what actually happened.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Don't make abstract statements about 'growth'. Explain specifically: what changed? How did the legal system respond? What was the outcome?

feedback_items.weak_passage: It impacted the symbolisms of cases and historical knowledge to me through cases like Brown v The Board of education and Plessy V Ferguson.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You talk about Brown versus the Board of Education and again, you don't actually tell me what happened in that case, what you learned in that case. The whole point of this is they want to see how you think, what you learned. When you read something, what kind of insights did you draw? But you're not telling me any of that. It reads more like a summary.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: For each case, explain: What was the legal question? What did the court decide? What was the impact? What insights did you draw about legal reasoning or social change?

feedback_items.weak_passage: It gave me insights on the principles of being a lawyer and how it may seem like a minor change to others it creates a massive impact on another individual.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You mention impacts, you mention minor changes, but again, not what those impacts are, not what those minor changes are. It's the same as just going on and on and saying things, things, something that, you see what I mean? So you need to be a bit more specific there.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Give a SPECIFIC example: 'In the case of X, the court's decision on Y led to Z outcome, which affected [specific group] by [specific way].'

feedback_items.weak_passage: I have delved into cases and trials myself by participating in my school's law societies mock trials.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I don't think you need to have an intro sentence. You can just say in one of the trials that we did as part of law society, you know...
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Start directly: 'In a mock trial for my school's law society, we examined [case name]...'

feedback_items.weak_passage: This allowed me to gain a deep understanding on how to gather information and the process of how legal cases plays out. I developed crucial skills that are used in law namely critical thinking and legal reasoning
feedback_items.your_feedback: You said this allowed me to gain a deep understanding on how to gather information. Can you not just say, we gathered this type of information, and this showed me how this particular legal case played out. It's a common theme - you list and you summarise, and it sounds a little bit commercial byline type thing. You're giving all the buzzwords, all the definitions of law, but you're not actually telling me what you learned, what you find interesting, what you drew from an experience.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Instead of stating you developed skills, SHOW it: 'We gathered evidence including X and Y. This showed me how [legal principle] applies in practice when [specific situation].'

feedback_items.weak_passage: My inquisitiveness for law flourishes outside of formal education, I have taken active steps to prepare for a career in law by immersing myself in both legal experiences and broader personal development.
feedback_items.your_feedback: That's the kind of sentence that just adds absolutely nothing. You can just go straight into, as a member of my school's law society, I shadowed a solicitor at somewhere, and I found this thing interesting. That's the kind of way you want to do it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this sentence entirely. Start directly with your law society experience.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My commitment to the Silver and Gold Duke of Edinburgh Awards have equally been formative. Leading expeditions and coordinating group responsibilities have cultivated leadership, resilience and problem-solving
feedback_items.your_feedback: With DofE, I would just say 'I took part in DofE' unless that's going to go in the reference, and then nothing else about it. I'm not gonna mention my leadership, resilience, problem solving skills. You shouldn't be the one saying that. They will infer that.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either remove DofE entirely (if it's in your reference) or reduce to: 'I completed Silver and Gold DofE' with no skill descriptions.
feedback_items.strong_passage: During the volunteer component I volunteered at an elderly care charity which reinforced my awareness of social accountability, particularly in supporting marginalised groups, aligning closely with my interests of medical negligence law
feedback_items.why_strong: The volunteer component has a clear connection to the student's stated interest in medical negligence law.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I have participated in a range of legal and business enrichment programmes including Slaughter and May's virtual law experience, the University of Brighton outreach and Surrey's Scholar events, Lloyds Bank insight scheme, Springpod, and the Power up seminar for aspiring lawyers.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You list off all the enrichment programmes you did. Again, better to just list it, but then you should go into a bit more detail about one of them and a specific thing that you learned.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: List the programs in one sentence, then pick ONE and explain: 'At [program], I learned about [specific legal concept/process]. This was particularly interesting because [why].'

feedback_items.weak_passage: As Head of student Diversity and inclusion, I have led initiatives that promote representation and fairness within my school community. Developing skills in communication and ethical leadership.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Diversity inclusion, developing skills and communication, they know that. I think it's interesting stuff. I would just maybe try and cut that down to half.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Reduce to: 'As Head of Student Diversity and Inclusion, I led initiatives promoting representation in my school.' No skill descriptions.
feedback_items.strong_passage: My involvement with the Doncaster Youth Council and speaking in the House of Commons in parliament where I debated the advocation of more mental health professional training in schools
feedback_items.why_strong: Parliament speaking experience is concrete and impressive.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You really need to challenge yourself to think, OK, is this part necessary? Has this added anything? If it hasn't, just get rid of it. This whole personal statement could be cut down by more than 50%. I think like 60% could go, and then you can add a little bit to it, and then it'll be perfect.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut 60% of current content - remove all buzzwords, skill descriptions, and vague statements. Then add specific details about cases, readings, and what you learned.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Really good sections, good work, this isn't gonna be the time consuming part, this part won't be difficult. You've done all the work, you just need to put it on paper.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: The content and experiences are there - focus on rewriting to show depth and specific learning rather than listing activities.
feedback_items.why_strong: Student has good experiences and content, just needs to reframe how it's presented.
